ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained the ability to compile a set of instructions in a hardware description language all the way into an asynchronous circuit.

I learned how the full process for chip design works, from conceptual designs to fabrication technologies. I learned how to build logic elements from transistors, how to write digital logic circuits in special languages similar to HDLs, and how to draw layouts for physical chips (as if they were to be manufactured). I also learned the concepts behind asynchronous circuits, including all the timing considerations that designers must deal with to ensure that their chip works properly.

Topics covered: transistor physics, transistor-level circuit design, designing circuits as functional blocks, communication between circuits when transferring data, designing an asynchronous-synchronous circuit interface

Things you should have: experience writing hardware description languages, experience writing C, basic understanding of semiconductor device physics
I learned a lot about sillicon and semiconductor design
Ability to design asynchronous systems at a high level and convert them to circuits.
Transistor level design and implementation of simple algorithms in hardware

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: Professor Manohar's engaging lectures and care for his students. He was understanding and lenient and structured everything in the course around facilitating student learning, nothing felt arbitrary or impractical. Weaknesses: The tools we had to use in the class were relatively poorly documented and un-googlable, unfortunately there is not much getting around this due to how niche the subject is.

Strengths: This course is really good as a senior elective because it ties together all the knowledge and skills from previous engineering/CS courses; this course is a logical culmination of an undergrad program in EE/EECS. This course also the exact area of research that Professor Manohar's lab works on, so Prof. Manohar is very knowledgeable and very passionate about the subject matter. 

Weaknesses: I think this course throws too much at us all at once. The nature of the course content (designing an asynchronous chip at all levels of abstraction) requires us to have prior expertise in/learn a lot about many topics in rapid succession. In theory, this is a great course for someone who already understands a lot of these topics or is a super genius, but realistically, it's very tough for most undergrads. For our projects, we were required to use a special language developed by Prof. Manohar's lab, which added a layer of difficulty to our projects. Not only did we need to come up with a good conceptual design, we also had to figure out how to implement it in a language that we had never seen before. The software tools we were required to use for our projects also required a lot of set-up time (because we had to install/use Docker), which also added another layer of complexity.  I talked to some other students in the class, and we were all constantly struggling to keep up, even when we helped each other out.
Strengths were that it was clearly presented mostly, however for the handshaking stuff there could have been more of an expansion
The only thing that can be improved, in my opinion, are the tools used. They are outdated and have a few bugs.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would certainly recommend this course to any student interested in a challenging and rewarding upper-level electrical engineering course, especially those interested in low level CS/computer engineering.

I have mixed feelings about this course. This class is definitely the most interesting class I've ever taken at Yale, as far as the content goes. However, the projects require a lot of work and are extremely tough to execute well. Furthermore, it's easy to become disengaged in lecture if you don't understand everything perfectly; if you don't completely understand the contents of one lecture, you can forget about trying to understand any remaining lectures on the same topic. 

I would recommend this class if you are very interested in learning how chips are designed, from beginning to end, from top to bottom, but only if you have a lot of experience in this area/are a genius/are willing to spend the majority of your time on this one class.
I would if you like chips. There's not many courses like it at Yale.
If you are interested in novel (even unconventional) methods in semiconductor circuit design
